channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Live Video and Social Media Updates From Ukraine
item.description: Video and social media updates on a day of upheaval in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Yulia Tymoshenko, Ukraine's former prime minister and a leader of the 2004 revolution, seemed to be fighting back tears as she addressed protesters in Kiev on Saturday night.

item.title: U.N. Orders Both Sides in Syria to Allow Humanitarian Aid
item.description: The resolution, unanimously adopted by the Security Council, calls on the Syrian government to allow relief agencies to enter the country, and strongly condemns terror attacks, plainly referring to some of the rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Lede: Venezuela Battles Media, Social and Otherwise, to Restrict Protest Coverage
item.description: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday, as protesters turned out for a tenth day of demonstrations and the government continued to clamp down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured
item.description: Mexican marines and the police, aided by information from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Marshals Service, took him into custody without firing a shot.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and GINGER THOMPSON
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was escorted to a helicopter in handcuffs in Mexico City on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Leader Flees the Capital; Elections Are Called
item.description: Former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko was released from prison, and Parliament found President Viktor F. Yanukovych unable to fulfill his duties and set an election for May 25 after he fled the capital.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Viktor Yanukovych denounced a “coup” on TV.

item.title: In a First for Spain, a Woman Is Convicted of Inciting Terror Over Twitter
item.description: The case is one of a recent handful that have pushed social media into courtrooms worldwide and raised issues of the limits of speech on the Internet.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Alba González Camacho, 21, posted messages calling for politicians to be killed.

item.title: Nearly 30 Die as Kurds Take a Syrian Town
item.description: If the Kurds can hold on to the town, Tell Brak, on a highway between the cities of Hasaka and Qamishli, it will be a significant advance in their quest for wider control in the northeast.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Italy Swears In New Prime Minister, 39, After Ouster
item.description: Matteo Renzi was sworn in on as Italy’s youngest prime minister, promising a new era of stable government after using old-school politicking to engineer the ouster of a fellow party member he deemed too timid to get the nation back to work.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Out of a Broken Promise and an Old Fight: Chaos
item.description: Three core factors led to the chaos in Ukraine: a broken promise between a leader and his people, a lingering Cold War-era fight, and public outrage at the government’s response to protests.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: News Analysis: With President’s Departure, Ukraine Looks Toward a Murky Future
item.description: Gone along with President Viktor F. Yanukovych was any trace of a Friday peace deal that had sought to freeze the country’s tumult.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: The Lede: Video and Tweets From Kiev’s Independence Square
item.description: As live video streams and messages posted on social networks from Kiev’s Independence Square showed, Ukrainian protesters remained defiant on Friday, calling for the resignation of the president.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Amid Fence-Mending, Another U.S.-Russia Rift
item.description: The political crisis in Ukraine has underscored the difficulties of restoring constructive ties between Washington and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama talked for an hour on Friday with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: U.S. Army Seeks Better Ties With China’s Military
item.description: As tensions rise between China and other Asian nations, a top U.S. general is working on improving contacts with China’s military.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Frankfurt Strike Stalls Flights
item.description: A strike by the security staff at Frankfurt Airport caused dozens of flight cancellations and delayed thousands of passengers, creating chaos at Europe’s third-largest airport on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: Rebels Control Major City
item.description: South Sudan’s government said Friday that rebel fighters were in control of Malakal, the capital of Upper Nile State, after several days of heavy fighting.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: New Prime Minister Picks His Cabinet
item.description: Matteo Renzi will be sworn in as Italy’s youngest prime minister on Saturday after he cobbled together a government he said would change the face of the country’s politics and economy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Police Fired Rubber Bullets at Migrants
item.description: Spain’s Interior Ministry on Friday posted videos online showing police officers firing rubber bullets as African migrants swam into Spanish territory from Morocco.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Response From Latin American Leaders on Venezuelan Unrest Is Muted
item.description: Street protests in which at least four have died do not evoke the type of criticism that is reserved for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, left, with President Raúl Castro of Cuba, in uniform, and other leaders last month.

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Office Criticizes Australia Detention Policies
item.description: Australia’s treatment of asylum seekers sent to offshore processing centers is cruel, inhuman and degrading and it violates international law, the United Nations’ human rights office said Friday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Libyan Plane Crashes, Killing 11
item.description: A medical flight from Libya crashed in a field near Tunis before dawn on Friday after an engine caught fire, killing all 11 Libyans on board, Tunisia’s civil defense agency said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Growing Support, and Tea From Young Women, Embolden Kiev Street Fighters
item.description: Young men on the front lines of the antigovernment protest said the adulation expressed by many people in Ukraine’s capital has inspired them to keep fighting.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday. Many people in the capital consider the fighters heroes.

item.title: Ukraine Has Deal, but Both Russia and Protesters Appear Wary
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to reduced powers and Parliament moved to free his imprisoned rival, but many protesters want him to resign.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Tensions in Ukraine spilled over into Parliament on Friday, but lawmakers still approved several steps aimed at easing the crisis.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Struggles of Artist With His Work, Hints of Mexico’s Own
item.description: Damián Ortega’s installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City has become a commentary on modern Mexico, in even more ways than he had intended.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I thought it would be interesting to have a public plaza with something intimate and individual,” the Mexican artist Damián Ortega said.

item.title: With Tumult Around Him, Russian Diplomat Keeps Calm
item.description: Vitaly I. Churkin finds his country the focus of international attention both at home with the Olympics, and at the United Nations.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Vitaly I. Churkin, the Russian ambassador to the United Nations, will vote Saturday on a resolution on humanitarian aid to Syria.

item.title: Syrians Seek New Delay in Export of Chemical Arms
item.description: The Syrian government has asked for a delay until mid-May for the export of its chemical weapons arsenal, an indication that the country’s pledge to eradicate that arsenal is fraying.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
